newsitem.title: UK: FORECAST-UK October global trade gap seen tighter.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST-UK October global trade gap seen tighter.

text.p: The trade gap between Britain and the rest of the world is expected to have slimmed significantly in October, helped by a sharp fall in the non-EU trade deficit, analysts said.
While markets will be wary of any sign that tighter monetary policy and a sturdy currency are undermining exports, analysts said these influences were unlikely to show through just yet.
"Interest rates have fed through to the exchange rate but I think it will be some time before they feed into exports," said Nick Stamenkovic, economist at DKB International in London.
"Sterling's recent strength will undermine exports, but I would be very surprised if it was evident as early as in the November data," he said.
A Reuter poll of economists suggests the October global trade deficit will have narrowed to 659 million stg from 899 million stg in September.
November's non-EU trade gap is expected to widen to 641 million stg from 424 million previously. Both numbers are due at 0930 GMT on Tuesday.
"Data already published revealed a sharp contraction in the non-EU trade deficit during October," said David Philpotts, economist at Schroder Economics in London.
"This bodes well for the whole world figure."
Data released last month showed a dramatic tightening of the non-EU trade gap for October, which almost halved to 424 million stg from 805 million stg in September.
Imports from non-EU countries remained reasonably level, dipping to 6,696 million stg from 6,710 million stg in Sepember.
Philip Uglow, economist at Union Discount in London, said the hefty 899 million stg gap in September global trade could be put down to a deterioration in the non-EU position.
But he also expected the improvement seen in last month's data to filter through on Tuesday.
"Given that we expect to see only a slight widening of the EU balance, we are forecastng the total shortfall to narrow to 575 million stg in October," he said.
Analysts said financial markets would keep a keen eye on imports figures in the worldwide trade data, watching for any evidence that the consumer recovery was boosting buying of foreign goods.

"Traditionally the UK has suffered from a high level of import penetration," said Stamenkovic. "And given that consumer spending is picking up, markets will be nervous if there is any significant rise in imports."
